notes: On 12 September 2019, representatives of civic groups such as Taiwan Citizen Front and TAHR: Taiwan Association for Human Rights held banners and staged a press conference outside the Legislative Yuan (Taipei City-Zhongzheng) to announce an upcoming parade in solidarity with Hong Kong and anti-extradition. [size= no report]

On 12 September 2019, more than 200 students from the Chinese University of Hong Kong joined a rally on campus in Ma Liu Shui near Tai Po demanding the school to remove internship or exchange in mainland China as part of the degree requirement for some degree programmes. They then marched to a building to submit a petition letter. [size=more than 200]

On 12 September 2019, a few hundred students and alumni from at least nine schools formed a human chain in the Eastern district of Hong Kong stretching from Fortress Hill to Causeway Way to call for the realisation of the five demands. They sang songs and shouted slogans. [size=a few hundred]

actor2: Rioters (China)
notes: On 12 September 2019, more than 30 young protesters gathered at Ap Lei Chau Estate Bus Terminal in the Southern district of Hong Kong to sing anti-ELAB songs. During the protest, six protesters were burnt by three nitric acid bottles thrown from a building. They were all hospitalised. [size=more than 30]

On 12 September 2019, members from the Defend Hong Kong Campaign protested at the Court of Final Appeal in Central to demand the resignation of the Honourable Chief Justice Geoffrey Ma. They were dissatisfied with the situation where they believed police arrest people and the judiciary releases them, which would encourage young people to participate in violent actions. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: Students (China); Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; Neo Democrats
notes: On 12 September 2019, around 500 students and alumni from eight schools in Tseung Kwan O near Sai Kung formed a human chain in Tseung Kwan O to support the recent protests. They shouted slogans 'liberate Hong Kong, the revolution of our times' and sang songs satirising the police force. A district councillor and a member from Neo Democrats were also present. [size=around 500]

In the evening of 12 September 2019, more than 1000 five-demands protesters gathered at the IFC Mall in Central to symbolise 'taking over' the mall from pro-Chinese government supporters who gathered in the same place earlier that day. The protesters formed a human chain, sang songs, and shouted slogans such as 'fight for freedom, stand with Hong Kong'. They also called for the realisation of the Five Demands. [size=more than 1000]

On 11 September 2019, more than 1000 people gathered at the Sha Tin New Town Plaza to mourn the dead in the 911 incident. During the event, they protested by singing songs such as 'do you hear the people sing' and 'Glory to Hong Kong', a song widely sung by anti-ELAB protesters. Some protesters closed the MTR exits and took away some parts of the MTR gates. Around 20 riot police officers entered the MTR station, and were booed by around 50 protesters who were encouraging citizens to jump over the gates. [size=more than 1000]

On 11 September 2019, a few hundred protesters gathered at Tai Koo MTR station in Tai Koo, in the Eastern district of Hong Kong, to mourn those who were injured on 11 August in Tai Koo during clashes with the police. Protesters sang songs, shouted slogans and called for the realisation of the five demands. [size=a few hundred]

On 9 September 2019, a few hundred people gathered at Tai Koo Shing Centre in Tai Koo, Eastern district of Hong Kong to show support for the anti-ELAB movement by singing songs and shouting slogans. They called for the government's response to the Five Demands. [size=a few hundred]

source: The Stand News; Radio Free Asia
notes: On 9 September 2019, more than 100 students and alumni of a secondary school in Tai Po protested by forming a human chain outside the school to support the arrested fellow students at Tai Po Market MTR station on 7 September 2019, during which the head of a student was severely hurt by a police baton. Some students and parents from a nearby primary school also joined the protest. Some protesters then marched to the Tai Po Police Station to file a complaint against police's use of excessive force against students. They shouted slogans 'liberate Hong Kong, the revolution of our times'. [size=more than 100]

On 9 September 2019, students from the City University of Hong Kong and Baptist University of Hong Kong gathered at Cornwall Street in Kowloon Tong near Kowloon City to demand the government to respond to people's five political demands. Some students formed a human chain on the campus of City University of Hong Kong and shouted slogans. In addition, a mother and her three daughters also protested outside Pui Ching Primary School in the same district over the same demands. [size=at least 4]

actor2: Rioters (China)
notes: On 9 September 2019, as part of the citywide 'human chain activity' and class boycott initiated by students, some students formed a human chain outside their school in Tai Kok Tsui, an area west to Mong Kok in Hong Kong to call on the government to fulfil the Five Demands. During the protest, someone threw concrete from above, resulting in the injuries of one student and one alumnus of the school. On the same day, 3,200 students from the Polytechnic University of Hong Kong protested by forming a human chain in Hung Hom near Tsim Sha Tsui to call on the government to respond to people's five political demands. They shouted slogans and sang. [size=at least 3,200]

On 9 September 2019, dozens of alumni and students of a boys' secondary school in the Western District of Hong Kong protested outside their school to demand the principal to explain why the school used paper and plastic bags to cover up students' memo paper during the class boycott activity on 2 and 3 September. They shouted slogans. The school requested one representative from the protesters to voice his or her opinion inside the school but the protesters declined this proposal, citing that no one was representative of the group. [size=dozens]

On 9 September 2019, more than 100 students joined a rally at the Education University of Hong Kong in Tai Po and formed a human chain to show support for the Five Demands Movement. Students shouted slogans. [size=more than 100]

On 8 September 2019, up to 10,000 people attended an authorised march from Chater Garden to the US Consulate-General in Central to urge the US government to pass the Hong Kong Human Rights Act, a new version of a previously submitted draft law which, if passed, will impose penalties upon Hong Kong and mainland Chinese officials who infringe upon 'basic freedoms' in the city, including freezing their US-based assets and being denied entry into the US. Protesters chanted 'free Hong Kong, democracy now.' and unfurled a large blue banner reading 'President Trump, please liberate Hong Kong' . [size=up to 10,000]

On 8 September 2019, a house church meeting venue in a village in Zhangwang Township (Zaozhuang City, Shandong Province) was raided by government officials. All future gatherings were banned for indefinite period due to the on-going 'riots' in Hong Kong. The officials threatened to dismiss the village's Party secretary and the village head if there was to be any future gatherings.

actor1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
actor2: Demosisto
notes: On 8 September 2019, Hong Kong activist Joshua Wong, also the secretary-general of Demosisto, was arrested at the Hong Kong International Airport in Chek Lap Kok when he was on his way to Berlin, for breaching his bail conditions. Wong believed this was a mistake as the court had approved his trip.

source: Ming Pao; HK01; HKFP; Apple Daily Hong Kong; St Paul Political Concern Group; Bastille Post
notes: On 6 September 2019, around 200 students and alumnae of a girls' secondary school staged a protest in front of their Leighton Road campus in Causeway Bay, Wan Chai district (Hong Kong) against the school's handling of students or alumni who conducted activities in the spirit of the anti-ELAB movement (class boycotts, distributing flyers), or used accessories (ribbons, masks) to indicate their political stance. The protesters wore ribbons, formed a human chain, sang songs, and held placards which said their students were not 'blind rebellion spirits.' [size=around 200]

On 6 September 2019, people joined a rally organised by the Social and Political Organisation Workers' Union at Chater Garden in Central, Hong Kong against police's indiscriminate arrest and the authoritarian way the SAR government was managing the society. They said they were not afraid of white terror and would continue to protest until their demands were met. Organisers said 23000 people attended while police put the figure at 3850. More than 10 police officers stood by. [size=3850-23000]

On 6 September 2019, about 400 to more than 500 faculty members of the Chinese University of Hong Kong gathered on campus in Ma Liu Shui near Tai Po to protest against police's arrests and excessive use of violence against protesters. They formed a human chain and shouted slogans. [size=about 400 to more than 500]

On 5 September 2019, a day after the Chief Executive announced the withdrawal of the Extradition Bill, senior protesters protested at the Office of the Chief Executive in Admiralty, Central and Western District (Hong Kong) to express their disatisfaction that the government had not responded to all the Five Demands and to invite the Chief Executive to join an open forum on 8 September to discuss how to handle the aftermath of the anti-ELAB movement. Meanwhile, some medical and nursing students from the University of Hong Kong formed a human chain from the Medical school on campus to Queen Mary Hospital in the Western district of Hong Kong, demanding that the government to respond to all of the five demands, and 'not one less'. [size=at least some]

On 5 September 2019, more than 100 students and alumni from a boys' secondary school formed a human chain outside the school in the Western district of Hong Kong to show their support for the anti-ELAB and Five Demands movement and to show their discontent with the school's restriction of students' freedom of expression. They shouted slogans. [size=more than 100]

On 5 September 2019, about 300 students from Lingnan University in Tuen Mun, Hong Kong staged a rally on campus to demand an explanation with regard to the removal of a pro-government chancellor from the board. They questioned why the chancellor has still not yet been removed from office more than one month after the July 21 Yuen Long attack, where he was filmed praising the attackers for doing a good job in the mass attack. Students shouted slogans calling for the Five Demands to be fulfilled and held banners. They then marched to an administrative building. The principal showed up and said students had no rights in determining the removal of chancellors from office. The principal promised to reply to the demands of the students by 9 September. [size=about 300]
On 4 September 2019, Thai students demonstrated in kwaeng Wang Mai, Pathum Wan district of Bangkok, Thailand, in support of the protest in Hong Kong. [size=no report]

actor1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
source: South China Morning Post; Radio Free Asia
notes: On 4 September 2019, the Chief Executive of Hong Kong announced that the anti-extradition bill that had sparked mass demonstrations in Hong Kong for the last three months would be officially withdrawn. She promised to set up an investigative platform to look into the fundamental causes of the social unrest and suggest solutions for the way forward - though stopping short of turning it into a full-fledged commission of inquiry as demanded by protesters. Protester said they did not accept this arrangement and said they would keep protesting until the government responded actively to the Five Demands.

On 4 September 2019, dozens of students of a secondary school in Siu Sai Wan in Eastern District of Hong Kong gathered outside their school to demand the chancellor of the school, a renowned businesswoman who recently denounced the anti-ELAB campaign at the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva, to have a dialogue with the students. Almost 100 supporters showed up to support them, shouting slogans. [size=more than 100]

On 3 September 2019, nearly 50 students from the Po Leung Kuk Lee Shing Pik College in Tsuen Wan District (New Territories, Hong Kong) staged a sit-in outside of the school gate to continue the protest sparked by the extradition bill and against the police. They wore helmets and face masks and shouted slogans such as 'black police, return the eye' referring to an earlier incident during which the police shot an eye of a girl who was protesting. [size=nearly 50]

source: Inmediahk.net; Radio Free Asia; Ming Pao
notes: On 3 September 2019, protesters rallied at Tamar Park in Admiralty in support of the citywide strike and class boycott for the second day. They demanded that the government responded to people's Five Demands before 13 September 2019. Organisers said over 40000 people attended the rally while police put the number at 4080. On the same day, around 20 alumni from a local secondary school organised a protest outside the school in Western district of Hong Kong to support the Five Demands class boycott taken place in their alma mater, despite having been disapproved by the school entity. They shouted slogans to show they stood with the current students. In the morning, 80 current students joined the class boycott at the school. [size=4080-40000 in total]

notes: On 3 September 2019, the chairman of local political party Demosisto, Ivan Lam, was taken away by the police at the Hong Kong International Airport on charges that he had 'incited others to participate in unauthorised assemblies' and 'participated in an unauthorised assembly'. This is in relation to the mass protest that took place near police headquarters on June 21.

source: The Stand News; RTHK; Ming Pao
notes: On 2 September 2019, about 400 medical staff of Queen Mary Hospital in Western district of Hong Kong formed a chain of people similar to the Hong Kong Way. The action was in protest against police actions in recent Five Demands protests and in response a call to workers and students to go on strike today to urge the government to fulfil the Five Demands. They shouted slogans and asked that the police behaved appropriately. [size=about 400]

On 2 September 2019, student groups protested outside the Mainland Affairs Council in the Zhongzheng District, Taipei City. These group demanded the council open a dialogue with the Hong Kong government on advising them to resolve a conflict through discussions. [size=no report]

On 2 September 2019, as part of a class boycott, approximately 30,000 students joined a sit-in protest at the Chinese University of Hong Kong in Tai Po to pressure the government to respond to people's five political demands. They held banners. [size=approximately 30,000]

assoc_actor_1: HKFTU: Hong Kong Federation of Trade Unions; Labour Group (China)
notes: On 2 September 2019, some members of the Hong Kong General Union of Security and Property Management Industry Employees, an affiliated union of HKFTU, marched to the Government headquarters in Admiralty to express the view that employees from property management offices and security guards were innocent and therefore should not be targeted by protesters in the anti-ELAB protests. [size=some]

actor2: Private Security Forces (Taiwan)
notes: On 2 September 2019, about 20 students from the student group of the National Dong Hwa University protested outside the Hong Kong Economic, Trade and Cultural Office in Xinyi District, Taipei City. They demanded the Hong Kong government to return the Hongkonger student who participated in the Anti-ELAB protest. The building security intervened in the protest. [size=20]

On 1 September 2019, around 600 people joined a protest at the British Consulate Hong Kong in Admiralty. Some waved the British Hong Kong flag and sang Britain's national anthem, demanded that they receive full British Citizenship and full UK passports to replace their second-class British National (Overseas) passports. [size=around 600]

actor2: Civilians (China)
notes: Around 1 September 2019 (beginning of month), the vice chairman of political party Demosisto was beaten by three men outside his family home in Hong Kong after he helped to organise a school strike. Violence has reportedly been increasing on both sides of the ideological divide in Hong Kong after a few months of demonstrations, and victims often include rally organisers, opposition lawmakers, student leaders and people standing for upcoming polls.

On 31 August, at least 200 to 300 members of the Tibetan Youth Congress held a demonstration march in New Delhi (NCT of Delhi) to express solidarity with the pro-democracy agitations in Hong Kong. [size=at least 200 to 300]

On 31 August 2019, an anti-government demonstration took place outside the terminal of Hong Kong International Airport on Lantau Island. Thousands of demonstrators shouted slogans, set up barricades and quickly retreated to Tung Chung MTR station as riot police arrived and cleared up the barricades at the airport. Demonstrators burnt the national flag and destroyed the MTR station. As the station was closed, many walked on a highway to evade mass arrest. They stopped at a toll plaza on the far end of the island where dozens of vehicles had arrived to transport the remaining crowds back to the city. [size=thousands]

actor2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
notes: On 31 August 2019, a non-partisan district councillor of Chai Wan was arrested at the Chai Wan MTR station in the Eastern district of Hong Kong. A group of people gathered outside the station to show their support for the arrestee, shouting slogans. Later, they walked to Chai Wan Police Married Quarters and blocked the entrance of the Quarters. Around 10 riot police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. [size=a group]

actor2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
notes: On 31 August 2019, a city-wide demonstration took place across Hong Kong Island after a march was banned by the police. Some demonstrators blocked roads, set fire, besieged government headquarters and threw bricks and petrol bombs, whereas riot police used tear gas, rubber bullets and water cannon trucks, which sprayed coloured liquid on demonstrators for easy identification. Some demonstrators who were attending an assembly in Central marched towards Western district. Demonstrators started a fire near the Police Headquarters on Hennessy Road. An undercover police reportedly fired a shot inside Victoria Park when surrounded by demonstrators. Foreign media has recorded one 'demonstrator' who threw a petrol bomb was suspected to arm with a police gun. [size=no report]

On 31 August 2019, between 65 and 500 parents protested at the Hong Kong Professional Teachers' Union in Mong Kok to demand the Union to stop inciting students to join recent protests and to boycott classes. Protesters shouted slogans. Organisers said 500 people attended the rally while police put the number at around 65. More than 10 riot police stood by. [size=65-500]

On 31 August, members of the Tibetan Women's Association held a demonstration march in Dharamsala city (Kangra, Himachal Pradesh) to express solidarity with the pro-democracy agitations in Hong Kong. [size=no report]

actor2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
notes: On 31 August 2019, as many as 300 anti-ELAB demonstrators (including students) rioted in Wanchai district (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong - Wan Chai) in the evening, after reported demonstrations across Hong Kong Island earlier in the afternoon. They removed open-air stands from the Southorn Playground to create roadblocks, and set fire outside 1 Hennessy Road. They threw bricks and Molotov cocktails against police officers, resulting in at least seven arrests. A social worker was arrested while attempting to intervene and mediate the situation. [size=as many as 300]

On 30 August 2019, more than 200 people joined a silent protest in Central, commemorating English and Canadian soldiers who sacrificed themselves to defend Hong Kong 74 years ago and to thank anti-ELAB protesters for their sacrifices for Hong Kong. They shouted slogans and covered their right eyes to show their support for a female protester who was shot in the eye by the police during one earlier protest. [size=more than 200]

On 30 August 2019, around 30 members of Defend Hong Kong Campaign and 20 members from a concern group called Hong Kong Citizens protested outside the Government Headquarters in Admiralty in Central and Western district (Hong Kong) to urge the government to legislate a mask ban. [size=around 50]

actor2: Civilians (China)

notes: On 30 August 2019, amidst the anti-extradition law protests, an off-duty police officer in charge of the armoury (arms inventory room) was chased and stabbed by three black-clad men across the street from Kwai Chung Police Station in Kwai Tsing district (Hong Kong). He suffered over 20 cuts and had four fingers severed.

actor2: Civilians (China)
notes: On 29 August 2019, a Hong Kong activist was attacked by four men of South Asian descent with metal rods and umbrellas in Tai Po while he was being interviewed by a reporter. This happened shortly after he was granted unconditional release by police following his arrest on 28 July for organising the 27 July Yuen Long demonstration. The activist was the person who initially applied for the letter of no objection for the Yuen Long demonstration on 27 July, but the march, which demanded that authorities launch an independent investigation into the Yuen Long attacks a week ago, was banned and a subsequent appeal was rejected.

assoc_actor_1: DAB: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong; HKFTU: Hong Kong Federation of Trade Unions
notes: On 29 August 2019, more than 10 members of the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong (DAB) and Hong Kong Federation of Trade Unions (HKFTU) petitioned at the Government headquarters in Admiralty to call on the government to legislate a ban on masks to prevent protesters from hiding their real identities. [size=more than 10]

actor2: Civilians (China)
notes: On 29 August 2019, a Hong Kong activist affiliated with Civil Human Rights Front (CHRF) and his friend were attacked by two masked men wielding a baseball bat and knife in Jordan in Yau Tsim Mong district. His friend was injured and hospitalised.

On 29 August 2019, almost 40 people gathered at North Point Police Station in the Eastern district of Hong Kong to show their support for the police. They gave away fruits and 20 boxes of sanitiser to the police. [size=almost 40]

On 28 August 2019, two pro-police protesters and a group of their supporters rallied at the Facebook HK branch in Taikoo Place, Quarry Bay in the Eastern district of Hong Kong against Facebook's action to close their accounts. A few hundreds people surrounded and verbally abused them. These two protesters demanded that Facebook explained why it closed their accounts. [size=two plus a group]

On 28 August 2019, over 1000 freshmen at the Chinese University of Hong Kong shouted slogan 'Liberate Hong Kong, the revolution of our times' during the orientation camps on campus in Tai Po. A few hundreds students held banners and shouted slogans, calling for the government to respond to their political demands related to the extradition bill and ask that the fellow students joined the class boycott starting the first week of September. [size=over 1000]

actor2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
notes: On 27 August 2019, more than 100 Five Demands demonstrators gathered outside Sham Shui Po Police Station and pointed laser pens at the station in Sham Shui Po, shouting slogans 'Liberate Hong Kong, revolution of our time'. Some demonstrators set up roadblocks using rubbish bins and debris. Police dispersed the demonstrators later on and took at least four demonstrators away. One arrestee claimed he just passed by the scene. Police did not explain the reason for his arrest. [size=more than 100]

On 26 August 2019, around 30 protesters gathered at the Revenue Tower in Wan Chai, Hong Kong to call on the government to respond to people's five political demands. Protesters showed slogans. Some Taiwanese also joined the sit-in protest. [size=around 30]

actor2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
notes: On 26 August 2019, more than 100 anti-ELAB demonstrators created roadblocks in Sham Shui Po using fences, rubbish bins, and other items, and pointed laser pens at Sham Shui Po Police Station, shouting slogans 'Liberate Hong Kong, revolution of our time'. Riot police confronted the demonstrators and arrested at least 2 people. [size=more than 100]

On 26 August 2019, around 30 taxi drivers protested outside the Government Headquarters in Admiralty in Central and Western district (Hong Kong) to denounce recent demonstrations against the extradition bill, which had caused a substantial decrease in their earnings. They called on the government to provide relief measures to taxi drivers, such as gas subsidy. [size=around 30]

actor2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
notes: On 25 August 2019, as a continuation of the anti-ELAB demonstration that took place on the same day in the Kwai Tsing and Tsuen Wan Districts, some demonstrators spread to Sham Shui Po in Hong Kong after the march. Riot police confronted the demonstrators outside Sham Shui Po Police Station and warned that they were participating in an illegal gathering. [size=no report]

On 25 August 2019, some protesters who self-claimed as family members of the Hong Kong police rallied at Edinburgh Place in Central to call on the government to set up an independent investigative committee to ease police-civil relations and to set up a platform for the public and the police to have a dialogue. They then marched to the Chief Executive's Office in Admiralty to hand in a letter outlining their demands. Organiser said 400 people joined the rally, while police put the number at 270. [size=270-400]

actor2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
notes: On 25 August 2019, as a continuation of the anti-ELAB demonstration that took place on the same day in the Kwai Tsing and Tsuen Wan Districts, some demonstrators spread to Tsim Sha Tsui in Hong Kong after the march. Demonstrators set up roadblocks and set fire to a flower rack outside Tsim Sha Tsui Police Station. Meanwhile, some demonstrators blocked the Hung Hom cross-harbour Tunnel. [size=no report]

actor2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
notes: On 25 August 2019, a march took place from Kwai Tsing District to Tsuen Wan District of Hong Kong to demand the realisation of the 'Five Demands'. Near Yeung Uk Road in Tsuen Wan, some demonstrators occupied a section of Road and created makeshift roadblocks. The police employed tear gas and water cannon to disperse the demonstrators. This was the first time the water cannon trucks were deployed. Some demonstrators pointed laser pens and threw eggs at the police. Police fired live bullets during the suppression of the demonstration. Five policemen were injured and hospitalised. There were physical clashes between some people dress in blue and the demonstrators in Tsuen Wan. Two people pulled out a weapon and raced to the demonstrators but backed off as the demonstrators chased back. 41 people were hurt and 54 were arrested. [size=no report]

actor2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
notes: On 24 August 2019, thousands of people marched from Tsun Yip Street Playground to the Zero Carbon Building in Kowloon Bay near Kwun Tong to oppose the extradition bill, to reiterate the five demands and to call for the dismantling of 'surveillance' lampposts. Demonstrators expressed concerns about recently installed smart lampposts enabled with facial recognition and video surveillance capabilities. Many worried that the lampposts would be used to further restrict freedom in Hong Kong, as China continues to tighten its grip. During the demonstration, rows of smart lampposts around the march route were dismantled by the demonstrators. Demonstrators occupied roads and surrounded Ngau Tau Kok police station. Police dispersed with tear gas. [size=thousands]

On 23 August 2019, around 30 members of a pro-government organisation went to Wong Tai Sin Disciplined Services Quarters in Wong Tai Sin to show their support for the Hong Kong police who have been safeguarding the city and people's properties. They gave the police and their relatives 20 boxes of honey and thank you cards as gifts. They also held banners and shouted slogans. [size=around 30]

On 23 August 2019, a group of people protested at the MTR headquarters in Kowloon Bay near Kowloon city against the company's action of not asking for help from the police when rioters demonstrated inside Yuen Long MTR station on 21 August and even sending them away with trains. Protesters were discontent with the company, citing that as a majority government-owned Hong Kong company, MTR should not be using public resources to protect rioters. [size=a group]

On the evening of 23 August 2019, an estimated 210,000 people participated in 'The Hong Kong Way' campaign, to draw attention to the movement's five demands. The action was inspired by a similar event that occurred in the Baltic States 30 years ago. Participants assembled at 7 pm on pavements along the three main MTR lines in Hong Kong - the Tsuen Wan line, Kwun Tong line and Island line - and to hold hands, creating three human chains totalling 60 kilometres long, stretching across both sides of Hong Kong harbour. [size=around 210,000]

On 23 August 2019, more than 500 taxis displaying national flags and patriotic posters drove on major roads of Hong Kong in a gesture of support for the government and police to stop the violence and restore peace in the city. This activity was co-organised by Safeguard HK and the Taxi Drivers and Operators Association, was held primarily in Hong Kong Island and Kowloon. Organiser said the parade was held to boost the image of Hong Kong, which was demaged by protesters who demonstrated at the airport and disturbed traffic. Apple Daily Hong Kong cited a source saying that taxi drivers who participated in the parade received HKD 800 each. [size=more than 500]

actor2: Civilians (China)
notes: On 22 August 2019, a member of Esuweiji - a group of doxxing websites focused on President Xi, CCP high officials and their relatives - was beaten up following his arrest by police officials in Maoming prefecture (Guangdong) (coded to Maonan). On the same day, a coordinated arrest of all members of the websites was conducted across their respective regions in China. The arrests were reported to be in connection with the webmaster - who was also arrested - travelling to Hong Kong on 22 June to observe the anti-ELAB demonstrations.

On 21 August 2019, around 30 members of Defend Hong Kong Campaign protested at the Hong Kong Professional Teachers' Union headquarters in Mong Kok to condemn the Union for inciting students to strike and to use this as an avenue to express their political opinion, deliberately damaging school operation and making students lose their opportunity to study and learn. Protesters shouted slogans. [size=around 30]

On 21 August 2019, some anti-ELAB students, staff members and alumni of the City University of Hong Kong joined a peaceful rally on campus in Kowloon Tong to demand the headmaster of the university to have a dialogue with his students regarding the five core demands and the recall of the extradition bill. Unable to see the headmaster, protesters stuck posters outside the administrative building. [size=no report]

On 21 August 2019, about 10 members of the Hong Kong MTR Staff General Association staged a protest at the MTR headquarters in Kowloon Bay to show their discontent with anti-ELAB protesters who bullied MTR frontline staff. [size=about 10]

source: ET Today; CNA; Liberty Times; New Talk; RTI (Taiwan); Taiwan News
notes: On 21 August 2019, about 150 medical staff, including members of the National Taiwan University Hospital Union and Taipei Doctors Union, protested in front of the National Taiwan University Hospital in Zhongzheng District, Taipei City in support of Hong Kong medical staff on strikes. [size=about 150]

On 20 August 2019, about 50 anti-ELAB masked protesters in full gear participated in a silent protest at Tuen Mun MTR station in Tuen Mun against deteriorating safety conditions in Hong Kong caused by police's excessive use of force against protesters. [size=about 50]

actor2: Civilians (China)
notes: On 20 August 2019, a Taiwanese voluntary consultant went missing after arriving in Shenzhen from Hong Kong. The Chinese government confirmed on 11 September that they had detained him under charges of endangering national security. He has been held incommunicado for more than 20 days since his detention.

actor2: Civilians (China)
notes: On 20 August 2019, at least 3 people (2 women and 1 man) were injured in a knife attack by an unidentified assailant at a Lennon Wall in Tseung Kwan O, Sai Kung District (New Territories, Hong Kong). It was reported that the assailant attacked the three people after hearing their political views.

On 20 August 2019, more than 100 people gathered outside Tai Koo MTR station in Tai Koo, Eastern district of Hong Kong to demand for the MTR company to disclose police operation inside the station on 11 August. MTR representative admitted having allowed the police to close certain exits but no request was made by the police for CCTV footage of the night. One man was found taking pictures of faces of the protesters and was forbidden from leaving the station by the protesters. He fell and was evicted by ambulancemen. [size=more than 100]

On 19 August 2019, many pro-China associations went to the police headquarters in Wan Chai to show support for the Hong Kong police in the recent anti-ELAB protests. Over 70 people were members of the Hong Kong Provincial People's Political Consultative Conference Association (HKCPPCC (Provincial) Members Association). They condemned rioters' actions of insulting the national emblem, disturbing public order and traffic and occupying the airport. They held banners and shouted slogans and gave snacks to the police to express their support. [size=over 70]

On 18 August 2019, more than 20 people protested outside the residence of a pro-democratic barrister, who is meanwhile the founder of the Democratic Party, in Mid-Levels in Central and Western district (Hong Kong) to condemn him for selling out Hong Kong to the United States and provoking chaos in Hong Kong. [size=more than 20]

assoc_actor_1: CHRF: Civil Human Rights Front; Five Demands Movement
notes: On 18 August 2019, the CHRF organised an anti-ELAB rally in Hong Kong island to condemn police brutality and reiterate the five core demands after the 11 August incident. According to CHRF, 1.7 million protesters had attended the rally. The police put the figure at 128,000. Protesters shouted slogans and marched from Causeway Bay to the Court of Final Appeal in Admiralty peacefully. MTR's trains skipped Causeway Bay station and Tin Hau station. Near the end of the rally, protesters briefly occupied sections of Harcourt Road outside the Government Headquarters, though some protesters called the people who stayed to go home to ensure that the protest could end peacefully. [size=128,0000-1,700,000]

The branch offices of pro-Beijing parties DAB and HKFTU were vandalised, and demonstrators hurled eggs at the offices. They placed pineapples, a metaphor for homemade explosives, outside HKFTU's office, reflecting their role during the Hong Kong 1967 leftist riots. Some demonstrators then moved to Mong Kok and besieged the Mong Kok police station. Demonstrators shouted slogans and set barricades to block roads in Mong Kok. notes: Around 15 August 2019 (between 9 August and 24 August), a former employee of the British consulate in Hong Kong was tortured by Chinese state security police during a 15 days' detention in Shenzhen City (Guangdong Province) and forced to confess about the British involvement in the anti-ELAB movement in Hong Kong. The man was reportedly arrested from Hong Kong West Kowloon Highspeed Railway Station on 9 August 2019. Chinese government only confirmed his arrest on 21 August 2019. He reported that he was restrained in a 'tiger chair' during interrogation, deprived of sleep, forced to do the spread-eagled pose for hours, and hold his hands up to prevent blood from pumping up his arms during the detention which caused extreme pain. He was forced to confess to crimes of 'soliciting prostitutes' and treason before being released on 24 August 2019.

He was detained for publicizing an op-ed about the anti-ELAB demonstrations in Hong Kong at Guanyinqiao Guangchang. Protesters held up signs calling for democracy, an investigation into the police's excessive use of force against protesters over the past month and the withdrawal of the controversial extradition bill, which was suspended on 15 June but not axed. On 15 June 2019, Tunghai University students gathered in Xitun district to voice support for the Hong Kong protests and oppose the proposed extradition bill in Hong Kong. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
actor2: Protesters (China)
notes: On 15 June 2019, more than 10 pro-democracy legislative councillors protested at the Police headquarters in Wan Chai (Hong Kong) to condemn the police force for using excessive violence against protesters during their operations. They submitted a petition letter. Meanwhile, around 10 members of the Hong Kong Chinese Importers' and Exporters' Association also gathered at Police headquarters in support of police action during protests. They thanked the police for maintaining stability of the city and donated 1 million HKD to a police welfare trust fund. [size=more than 20]

On 15 June 2019, more than 20 people gathered at the Hong Kong International Airport in Chek Lap Kok (Islands, Hong Kong) to protest against the extradition bill. They put signs around their bodies and displayed posters with anti-ELAB messages to spread anti-extradition bill messages. They were minor verbal altercations between the protesters and the pedestrians. [size=more than 20]

On 15 June 2019, more than 20 members of New Millenarian protested outside the North Point Police Station in North Point, Eastern district (Hong Kong) in support of the police force. They also condemned the violence during the anti-ELAB protests. They shouted slogans and held banners and placards. [size=more than 20]

On 14 June 2019, around 7 members of Demosisto protested inside Mei Foo MTR station near Sham Shui Po, Hong Kong against the extradition bill and to call on the people to go on strike and students to boycott classes. They knelt down and shouted slogans. [size=around 7]
On 14 June 2019, more than 500 students gathered at the National Taiwan University campus to protest against the proposed extradition bill in Hong Kong. [size=more than 500]

On 14 June 2019, between 980 and 6000 mothers joined an anti-extradition bill rally at Chater Garden in Central (Central and Western district, Hong Kong) to show support for the young people, to urge the government to withdraw the extradition bill, and to urge the Chief Executive to step down. They shouted slogans. Organisers said 6000 mothers participated in the rally while police put the highest turnout at 980. On the same day, more than 100 protesters gathered at the Tamar Park and a footbridge leading to the Legislative Council in Admiralty (Central and Western district, Hong Kong) to sing songs, read Bible and play music to protest against the extradition bill. They also held signs written 'we are not the enemies' and 'stop violence'. There were also people singing songs during the whole day. [size=more than 1080-6100 in total]

On 14 June 2019, more than 80 students and alumni of a secondary school joined a sit-in protest in their school in To Kwa Wan (Kowloon City, Hong Kong) to express dissatisfaction with the police's use of violence during clearance against students on 12 June and to urge the government to withdraw the extradition bill. [size=more than 80]

On 14 June 2019, nearly 100 National Sun Yat-sen University students and teachers gathered on campus to voice support for the Hong Kong protests and oppose the proposed extradition bill in Hong Kong. [size=nearly 100]

On 14 June 2019, members of the Alliance for Peace and Economy Hong Kong went to the Police headquarters in Wan Chai (Hong Kong) in support of the frontline police officers and police operation during recent protests. They donated food and water to the police. [size=no report]
On 14 June 2019, high school students in Changhua city gathered on campus to voice support for the recent Hong Kong protests. [size=no report]

At the same time, more than 100 people gathered at Tamar Park in Admiralty (Central and Western district, Hong Kong) to protest against the extradition bill. Some Christians sang songs to pray for Hong Kong, while some protesters volunteered to clean up the rubbish. [size=more than 115]

On 13 June 2019, around 20 people echoed a city-wide call for non-cooperation movement against the MTR company by gathering at the Tiu Keng Leng MTR station near Sai Kung, Hong Kong. They called on more people to join them to stay in the station. A man was injured his foot after getting it stuck between the train and the platform and was sent to hospital. Around 6-7 police officers were stationed nearby. The city-wide call was held as part of the broader anti-ELAB demonstrations to demand the government to withdraw the extradition bill. [size=around 20]

On 13 June 2019, Hong Kong students studying in Taiwan gathered at the Presidential Office to deliver a petition and call on the President to take concrete actions to support human rights protection in the region. [size=no report]

They held signs. [size=no report]

On 13 June 2019, more than 40 members of at least 4 pro-police groups went to the Police headquarters in Wan Chai (Hong Kong) to show support for the police force during the protests. They condemned the protesters whose actions threatened the stability and prosperity of Hong Kong. They shouted slogans, displayed a banner, and donated supplies to the police. [size=more than 40]

actor2: Civilians (China)
notes: On 13 June 2019, an activist from Hunan was forced to go on ''mandatory holiday'' after he was released from a detention centre in Hunan province. His phone has been confiscated and his whereabout was unknown by the time of reporting on 17 June 2019. The activist has been prosecuted after expressing support for the Occupy Central Movement in Hong Kong years ago. It was believed that he was temporarily prevented from returning home in order to prevent him from supporting the ongoing anti-ELAB demonstration in Hong Kong.

One of the hunger strike participants was a district councillor of the Wan Chai constituency, another was a professor. [size=at least 210 in total]

assoc_actor_1: CHRF: Civil Human Rights Front; Five Demands Movement
actor2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
notes: On 12 June 2019, as many as 10000 demonstrators echoed CHRF's call to paralyse traffic in Admiralty in an attempt to stall the second reading of the extradition bill in the Legislative Council in Admiralty (Central and Western district, Hong Kong). They rushed on Lung Wo Road and Harcourt Road to block traffic with barricades and railings in the morning. After the government announced that the second reading debate on the extradition bill had been postponed indefinitely, demonstrators still continued their demonstration. They shouted slogans demanding the withdrawal of the bill. Police dispersed the demonstrators with tear gas, pepper spray, rubber bullets, bean rounds bullets and batons, who responded by throwing water bottles and bricks at them. 22 police officers were reportedly injured and 11 people were arrested. The police's alleged excessive use of force and categorisation of the event as ''''riot'''' prompted the broader Five Demands Movement following this event (location coded as Hong Kong-Central and Western). [size=as many as 10,000]

On 12 June 2019, almost 30 people from Demosisto and other student organisations blocked a passenger channel inside Central MTR station (Central and Western district, Hong Kong) to encourage Hongkongers to go on strike on that day to oppose the extradition bill. They sat down and held signs. [size=almost 30]

On 12 June 2019, more than 500 National Cheng Kung University students gathered on campus to voice support for the Hong Kong protests and oppose the proposed extradition bill in Hong Kong. [size=more than 500]

assoc_actor_1: Christian Group (China); Five Demands Movement; Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
notes: On 11 June 2019, nine pro-democracy legislative councillors protested at the Government House in Central (Central and Western district, Hong Kong) to demand to speak to the Chief Executive and to demand her to withdraw the extradition bill. Over 20 police officers surrounded the councillors and demanded that they leave. Meanwhile, some pro-democracy legislative councillors protested against the extradition bill during a legislative council meeting in Admiralty by displaying banners, surrounding other legislative councillors, and telling off the chairperson of the meeting. On the same day, at least 2000 people gathered around the Legislative Council complex in Admiralty to protest against the extradition bill, which was to be tabled by the government for second reading in the Legislative Council on 12 June. Two councillors intervened when a police officer searched a protester who was suspected of possessing offensive weapons, but the police did not otherwise intervene in the demonstration. No arrest or injury was resulted; At the same time, some Christians also joined the rally outside the Government headquarters in Admiralty to demand the withdrawal of the extradition bill. This was the second day of the three-day protest initiated by Christian groups in Hong Kong. [size=at least 2009 in total]

On 11 June 2019, members of Hong Kong Island Women's Association and The Small and Medium Law Firms Association of Hong Kong staged a rally outside the Police Headquarters in Wan Chai (Hong Kong) in support of the police force and to condemn the anti-ELAB demonstrators for breaking into the Legislative Council on 9 June. [size=no report]

On 10 June 2019, dozens of students gathered in front of the Hong Kong Economic, Trade and Cultural Office to protest against the proposed extradition bill in Hong Kong and call on Taiwan's political parties to express their views on the Hong Kong protests. [size=dozens]

assoc_actor_1: CHRF: Civil Human Rights Front; Civilians (China); Demosisto; Five Demands Movement; Journalists (China); Students (China)
actor2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
source: Radio Free Asia; The Stand News; RTHK
notes: On 9 June 2019, between 240,000 and 1,030,000 people joined a march organised by CHRF from Victoria Park to the Government Headquarters in Admiralty (Central and Western district, Hong Kong) to oppose the extradition bill. The march was joined by students from various schools. Demonstrators shouted slogans. Police arrested 7 people during the demonstration, one of whom was involved in destruction of a street station, six were involved in a theft, and 1 in attacking a police officer. After the march, around 350 demonstrators clashed with the police outside the Government headquarters. They attempted to storm into the Legislative Council complex and threw bottles and metal barricades at police and pushed barricades while officers responded with pepper spray. 8 officers, some demonstrators and journalists were injured. Meanwhile, members from Demosisto staged a sit-in rally in the car park of the Legislative Council to demand a dialogue with the Chief Executive and the Head of the Security Bureau. 19 people were arrested during the incident. [size=240,000-1,030,000]

On 09 June 2019, hundreds of Hong Kong students studying in Taiwan gathered in front of the Hong Kong Economic, Trade and Cultural Office in Taipei to protest against the proposed extradition bill in Hong Kong. [size=hundreds]

notes: On 9 June 2019, many Christian and Catholic groups staged a praying rally outside the Central Library in Causeway Bay (Wan Chai, Hong Kong) before the march organised by CHRF to protest against the extradition bill. They said that the extradition bill could harm religious exchanges between Hong Kong and the mainland, which means that Hong Kong would no longer be able to support underground churches in China. They also believed the bill would raise fear for free speech. [size=many groups]

assoc_actor_1: The Alliance: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China; Labour Group (China); LSD: League of Social Democrats; Hong Kong Labour Party; PP: People Power; Students (China)
notes: On 4 June 2019, a few hundred up to more than 2,200 people marched, organised by The Alliance, from Victoria Park in Causeway Bay to the China Liaison Office in Sai Ying Pun (Central and Western district, Hong Kong) after the June 4 commemorative rally in Victoria Park to condemn the brutality of the Chinese central government. The march was joined by members of League of Social Democrats, People Power, Labour Party Hong Kong, Socialist Action and Student Labour Action Coalition. They shouted slogans and names of dissidents arrested in China. They demanded their immediate release and called on the Chinese central government to seek an official reassessment of the 1989 crackdown. They also called for the public to join the anti-ELAB march on 9 June. Outside the Liaison Office, they spread paper banknotes to the Office and hung a blood-covered piece of cloth there. [size=a few hundred up to more than 2,200]

A pro-Beijing lawmaker, also a member of BPA, attempted to replace a DP lawmaker to preside over the meeting as the head of the Bills Committee. However, his microphone was seized by a Council Front lawmaker and a Neo Democrats lawmaker. During the scuffle, the Neo Democrats lawmaker fell off from a table and needed to be sent to the hospital immediately. At the end of the chaos, 4 pro-Beijing lawmakers, including members of HKFTU and DAB, were also injured. The two camps both reported that the opposite side attacked them. [size=at least 14]

source: Wen Wei Po; Radio Free Asia
notes: On 12 February, the Security Bureau of Hong Kong submitted a proposal to the Panel on Security of the Legislative Council in Central and Western District to ammend the Fugitive Offenders Ordinance and the Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters Ordinance in order that authorities of the mainland, Hong Kong, and Taiwan could provide each other with legal assistance and carry out extraditions on a case-by-case basis for criminal offences. The proposal (known as the 'Extradition Bill' in most media reports) was sparked by the lack of legal recourse available to prosecute a Hong Konger who had committed a murder in Taiwan last March. It has since led to significant demonstrations across Hong Kong.

On 5 May 2018, nearly 150 elderly people and their families marched from the Legislative Council to the Chief Executive's Office in Central District (Hong Kong) with banners and placards. Protesters demanded the government to improve average individual space in nursing houses to 16 square meters to ensure privacy and better living conditions. [size=nearly 150]

assoc_actor_1: LJL: Land Justice League (Hong Kong); LSD: League of Social Democrats
notes: On 5 May 2018, more than 10 members of the LJL, the LSD and villagers who were forcibly evicted from their lands petitioned and demonstrated in Yuen Long District (Hong Kong). The protesters demanded the government to apply the Lands Resumption Ordinance and recover land hoarded by private developers to build more public housing. [size=more than 10]

On 5 May 2018, members of the Alliance of Monitoring Hong Kong Association of the Deaf group staged a protest outside the Cheung Hang Community Hall in Kwai Tsing District (Hong Kong) during the general assembly of the association over the association allegedly misappropriating the donations for the Peiliang International Kindergarten for the deaf children. The protesters held banners during the protest, and they were rejected to enter the community hall before the assembly, which led them to protest outside. [size=no report]

On 4 May 2018, at least 3 Demosisto members demonstrated at a school in Tai Kok Tsui, Yau Tsim Mong District (Hong Kong) where the Education Secretary was visiting on the same day. They stated that the Education Bureau should not allow the rewriting of Hong Kong's liberal studies curriculum and textbooks after the Education Bureau's Textbook Review Group criticized specific phrases in the books regarding Hong Kong's political status as being ''problematic''. Protesters held signs and called the government not to let politics come before education. [size=at least 3]

assoc_actor_1: CP: Civic Party (Hong Kong); DP: Democratic Party (Hong Kong); LSD: League of Social Democrats; The Alliance: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China; Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
source: Radio Free Asia; Apple Daily Hong Kong
notes: On 4 May 2018, more than ten members and a former Legislative Councillor from pro-democracy groups including CP, DP, LSD, and the Alliance, protested at the Liaison Office of the Central People's Government in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region in Western District, demanding the release of Liu Xia (widow of Nobel Peace Prize winner Liu Xiaobo), and activist lawyer who was arrested during the 709 crackdown. Protesters held banners and signs, shouted slogans and accused the CCP of ruthless suppression and torture of activists. [size=more than ten]

assoc_actor_1: Hong Kong Island Federation; Labour Group (China)
notes: On 3 May 2018, more than 60 people led by the Hong Kong Island Federation and the Southern District Community Association protested at the Legislative Council in Central District (Hong Kong) against an earlier incident in which a Democratic Party Legislative Councillor snatched the mobile phone of a female government official suspected of ''observing'' Legislative Council members. They urged the legislator to resign and demanded the Council and the police to open an investigation. On the same day, 40 members of the Federation of Hong Kong Kowloon New Territories Hawkers Association and Po Kin Hai Liu Association protested at the LegCo against the same incident and they demanded the LegCo to start the impeachment procedure against the legislator. [size=more than 100]

assoc_actor_1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; Demosisto; Christian Group (China); CP: Civic Party (Hong Kong)
notes: On 3 May 2018, at least 8 representatives and Legislative councillors from multiple parties and groups such as Demosisto, CP, and Christian Social Concern Fellowship went to petition at the Office of the Privacy Commissioner for Personal Data in Wan Chai District (Hong Kong) with a large banner. They claimed that the government had been sending administrative officers to work in the Legislative Council to monitor LegCo members and collect their personal information. Protesters demanded the Office to investigate the misconduct of the government. [size=at least 8]

On 2 May 2018, at least 20 citizens protested at the office of a Legislative Councillor at Shek Tong Tsui in Central and Western District (Hong Kong) with banners and placards. The legislator was involved in an incident of snatching the mobile phone of a female government official in the LegCo building while he suspected the government official was monitoring LegCo members. Protesters urged the legislator to resign for his inappropriate behaviour. [size=at least 20]

On 2 May 2018, several members of the Neo Democrats protested at the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department (AFCD) in Sham Shui Po, Hong Kong. Protesters held a banner and signs and demanded the AFCD strengthens its inspection and law enforcement on mainland tourists flocking into Hong Kong's parks and camping areas during the May Day holiday. Protesters complained that tourists were cutting down trees and setting fires, littering, fishing illegally, and violating the camping regulations of the AFCD. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: HKCTU: Hong Kong Confederation of Trade Unions; HKFTU: Hong Kong Federation of Trade Unions; Labour Group (China)
source: Ta Kung Pao; Radio Free Asia
notes: On 1 May 2018, HKCTU and around 30 other labour groups in Hong Kong organised a protest march from Southorn Playground and Causeway Bay to the Government Offices in Central District (Hong Kong) to urge the government to improve workers' rights. On the same morning, HKFTU also organised a march in the city and raised 4 demands, including: terminate the Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) offsetting mechanism; stop expanding labour import; stop government outsourcing; and 14 weeks' fully paid maternity leave. One source Ta Kung Pao placed the total number at 3,000 while HKFTU claimed that participants reached almost 5,000 in total. [size=3,000 to 5,000]

On 1 May 2018, three staff members of the Neighbourhood and Worker's Service Centre held a sit-in in Hong Kong after the May Day rally, protesting their sudden dismissal. A day before the sit-in, the three attended a meeting where Leung Yiu-chung, politician, Legislative Council member and Neighbourhood and Worker's Service Centre member, told them their salaries would not be paid anymore starting 31 May, but that they are not being fired. The three pointed at Leung Yiu-chung's plans to allocate resource for elections as the reason for the dismissal, but Leung denied the allegations. [size=three]

assoc_actor_1: CF: Council Front (Hong Kong); Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; DP: Democratic Party (Hong Kong); CP: Civic Party (Hong Kong)
source: The Stand News; RTHK; Apple Daily Hong Kong

[size=at least 10]

On 30 April 2018, around 30 people from Justice and Peace Commission of the Hong Kong Catholic Diocese, Christians For Hong Kong Society, Hong Kong Christian Fellowship of Social Concern, and Hong Kong Christian Institute staged a protest outside the Hong Kong Liaison Office in Central and Western District (Hong Kong) over the government of Mainland China suppressing religious freedom and cracking down religious institutions. Protesters held banners and a wooden cross circling around the Liaison Office. Earlier, a joint statement condemning the religious freedom suppression from the Mainland China government was drafted which was intended to send to various foreign embassies in Hong Kong, foreign media outlets, and international human rights organizations. [size=around 30]

assoc_actor_1: DP: Democratic Party (Hong Kong); Neo Democrats; Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
notes: On 30 April 2018, more than 40 members of several groups including DP, Neo Democrats (including Legislative Councillors) collectively complained and protested at the Office of the Ombudsman in Central District (Hong Kong) about government misconduct. Protesters held signs and argued that the government had exceeded its authority by sending administrative staff to the Legislative Council to monitor the whereabouts of its members. The event was triggered by an earlier incident in which a Democratic Party Legislative Councillor snatched the mobile phone of a government official suspected of ''observing'' Legislative Council members. [size=more than 40]

On 30 April 2018, a group of women workers from the Hong Kong Women Worker's Association and the Sanitation Workers Labour Union protested at the government headquarters in Admiralty, Hong Kong, demanding to amend labour laws and improve the legal protection of employees of marginal jobs. Protesters held a banner and signs. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: HKFLU: Federation of Hong Kong and Kowloon Labour Unions; Labour Group (China)
notes: On 29 April 2018, members of the HKFLU and other groups demonstrated at the Government Complex in Central District (Hong Kong) to petition. They demanded the government to cancel the Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) offsetting mechanism and reduce the number of migrant workers. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: Hong Kong Labour Party; LSD: League of Social Democrats; LJL: Land Justice League (Hong Kong)

notes: On 29 April 2018, nearly 30 people from six different groups including Labour Party, the LSD, the Concerning Grassroots' Housing Rights Alliance and the LJL protested at the Fanling Golf Club in Hong Kong North, urging the government to seize the land of the golf course and use it for residential purposes, affordable housing, and elderly retirement homes once the golf course lease terminates. Protesters held banners and signs and claimed that the land is being ''occupied'' by the rich. [size=nearly 30]

On 29 April 2018, between 1,900 and 5,000 people, organised by AnimalSaverHK, marched from the Chater Garden to the Legislative Council in Central District (Hong Kong) against animal cruelty and calling on the government to pass laws for animal protection, impose tougher penalties, and establish special department for animal protection. The marchers also held a vigil at Chater Garden in the district for a dog that was thrown by its owner from a 23-floor residential building and killed in March 2018. [size=between 1,900 and 5,000]

assoc_actor_1: HKFLU: Federation of Hong Kong and Kowloon Labour Unions; Labour Group (China)
notes: On 29 April 2018, more than 1,000 people led by the HKFLU and other groups marched from Sham Shui Po to Yau Ma Tei in Yau Tsim Mong District (Hong Kong) to demand the government to cancel the Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) offsetting mechanism and reduce the number of migrant workers. [size=more than 1,000]

assoc_actor_1: Demosisto; LSD: League of Social Democrats; CF: Council Front (Hong Kong); CP: Civic Party (Hong Kong); Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
notes: On 27 April 2018, at least 20 members of multiple pro-democracy groups including Demosisto, LSD, CP and CF and several legislative councillors gathered outside the Legislative Council in Central (Hong Kong) to support a LegCo member, Hui Chi-fung, after he was threatened with removal from office for snatching the phone of a female security bureau executive officer when suspecting a security breach. They held the opinion that Hui should not be removed from office although his act was not appropriate. [size=at least 20]

On 27 April 2018, members of several pro-Beijing groups, including All-China Women's Federation Hong Kong Delegates Association, demonstrated outside the Legislative Council in Central Hong Kong and urged a LegCo member, Hui Chi-fung, to resign from office he tried to snatch the phone of a female security bureau executive officer when suspecting a security breach. They held the opinion that Hui's act was a particular threat to women and privacy. [size=no report]

On 27 April 2018, at least dozens of people organised by the Labour Party held banners and staged a protest in support of developing the land of the Fanling golf course for housing outside the Fanling golf course in North District (Hong Kong). A man wearing the golf club's t-shirt was seen grabbing the neck of a Labour Party member and pushing him onto the ground during the protest. The golf club denied that the man was one of its staff. [size=at least dozens]

assoc_actor_1: Falun Gong Group (China); Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; Former Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

They also called for justice to be brought onto those who violated their rights and freedom. [size=dozens]

assoc_actor_1: Students (China); Teachers (China); Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
notes: On 24 April 2018, nearly 400 teachers and students from Hong Kong Polytechnic University gathered on campus in Kowloon City District (Hong Kong) to protest against the sudden layoff of nine part-time tutors by the university. Two legislative councillors also attended the event. They demanded taht the university reinstates these teachers' contracts. [size=nearly 400]

On 24 April 2018, at least 10 members of the Alliance for Children Development Rights protested outside the Youth Development Commission's first meeting in the government in Central District (Hong Kong) against the Commission's lack of transparency, closed-door meeting and dominating number of pro-Beijing members. On 22 April 2018, at least a dozen people led by a DP legislator protested at the headquarters of an estate development company in Wan Chai District (Hong Kong) to petition for people with autism. They urged the company to perform its social responsibility to reserve land in its development plan for building a support centre for people with autism. [size=at least a dozen]

assoc_actor_1: Labour Group (China); HKFTU: Hong Kong Federation of Trade Unions; Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

Protesters parked a dozen cabs outside the government headquarters to demand rapid action from transport officials. The protest was prompted by a fatal car accident involving an Uber car a few days prior. [size=nearly 30]

On 22 April 2018, a dozen citizens led by animal protection organisations such as ''Paws Hero'' and ''99 Bus'' protested outside of the Government Headquarters at Admiralty in Central District (Hong Kong) to urge the government to pass more comprehensive animal protection law. [size=a dozen]

On 21 April 2018, members of the Labor Party protested outside the East Kowloon Military Camp of the People's Liberation Army Hong Kong Garrison, demanding the government to reassess land allocation for military purposes. Protesters held a banner and signs and gave speeches. The protest precedes a five-month-long public consultation conducted by the Task Force on Land Supply that will begin on 26 April 2018. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; LSD: League of Social Democrats
notes: On 21 April 2018, more than ten members of social groups including the League of Social Democrats, and Legislative Council members protested outside a hotel where a conference on promoting Basic Law Article 23 was held in Tsim Sha Tsui Hong kong. Police dispatched a large number of police officers to prevent the protesters from harassing former chairman of the Hong Kong Basic Law Committee, Qiao Xiaoyang, who attended the conference and had to enter the hotel under police protection due to the protesters. Protesters held signs and shouted slogans such as ''End the one-party dictatorship in China'', ''Release all political prisoners'' and ''Oppose the Basic Law Article 23 legislation''. [size=more than ten]

On 21 April 2018, more than 100 conservationists protested outside two restaurants in Central District (Hong Kong) operated by the Maxim's Caterers Ltd to urge the corporation to stop selling shark fin. Protesters shouted 'eating shark fin is a wrong tradition; Maxim, stop selling shark fin' and handed petition letters to the two restaurants. [size=more than 100]

assoc_actor_1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; CP: Civic Party (Hong Kong)
notes: On 20 April 2018, about 40 members of the Protect Cha Kwo Ling Harbour Concern Group and residents of Laguna City gathered at the North Point Government Office (Eastern District, Hong Kong) and protested against the Town Planning Board's decision to build a vocational training school on the beachfront near Cha Kwo Ling in the district. Members of the Legislative Council and the Civic Party participated in the protest. Protesters held signs and banners and criticized the government for misusing East Kowloon seaside instead letting citizens enjoy the clean air and natural scenery, and demanded that the original plan for a seaside park should be executed instead. [size=about 40]

On 20 April 2018, at least 8 members of an organisation called Protect Harbourfront Community gathered at the Hong Kong Heritage Discovery Centre in Tsim Sha Tsui (Yau Tsim Mong District, Hong Kong) while the Lands Department was having a meeting there. They protested against the government for shutting down the General Post Office Headquarters in Central District, and advocated for preserving its historical and architectural value by converting it into a public space. They petitioned, held a large banner and shouted ''returning the harbour to the people''. [size=at least 8]

assoc_actor_1: DAB: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong; Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
notes: On 19 April 2018, a dozen people led by the DAB and two of its legislative councillors gathered at the Justice Place in Central Hong Kong to demand the Department of Justice to prosecute and charge the law professor that had recently spoke about the ''independence'' of Hong Kong at a conference in Taiwan. On 19 April 2018, at least a dozen members of the LSD gathered outside the High Court in Central Hong Kong with a large banner to protest against the MTR raising prices. They were also there to support the appeal hearing of a LSD member that was convicted in March 2017 for protesting against the MTR at Mongkok station. [size=at least a dozen]

assoc_actor_1: DP: Democratic Party (Hong Kong); LSD: League of Social Democrats; CP: Civic Party (Hong Kong); Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
notes: On 18 April 2018, at least dozens of members of DP, LSD, CP and district councillors gathered at the headquarter of the Link REIT in Kwun Tong District (Kowloon City, Hong Kong) to protest against the rising price of parking slots managed by the company and urge the government to provide more parking space in the district. On 17 April 2018, members of the Tsz Wan Shan Market Community Concern Group gathered to submit a petition signed by over 3000 residents of Tsz Wan Shan, Wong Tai Sin District (Hong Kong) to Housing Authority representatives attending a district council meeting. The petition expressed dissatisfaction about overcrowding and high rents at a local food market building that had been reduced to a single floor. [size=no report]

On 16 April 2018, at least 5 citizens gathered at the Hong Kong High Court in Central District with placards to deliver a petition letter to the High Court asking the High Court to revoke a previous decision of the Lands Department regarding the Fanling North New Development Area because the estate developing company had not conducted the project as promised. actor2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force

Protesters held signs and shouted slogans opposing further legislation such as ''People come before the county''. [size=nearly 10]

assoc_actor_1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
notes: On 15 April 2018, at least 5-6 people attended a gathering at the Civic Square (Central District, Hong Kong) to welcome the establishment of special units within Hong Kong police for investigating animal abuse cases. On 15 April 2018, hundreds of Falun Gong practitioners held a rally and called to stop the persecution of Falon Gong in China and for the disintegration of the CCP. The rally began in Cheung Sha Wan and ended in Tsim Sha Tsui Pier, Kowloon, Hong Kong. Protesters were holding signs and banners. [size= hundreds]

assoc_actor_1: CP: Civic Party (Hong Kong); Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; Teachers (China); The Alliance: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China

Participants held flags and banners, carried a statue of the Goddess of democracy, and called to end one-party dictatorship in China. [size=more than 20]

On 14 April 2018, 3 members of an environmental organisation, the Wild Aid, staged a silent protest with placards at a restaurant in the IFC building in Central Hong Kong over their use of shark fin. They were confronted by the restaurant staff and removed by security. No violence was reported. [size=3]

assoc_actor_1: DAB: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong; Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

On 12 April 2018, five Christians representing more than 20 Christian groups protested at the Chief Executive's Office in Admiralty, Central and Western District (Hong Kong), condemning the Hong Kong Government and Beijing for combatting Dai Yaoting for his ''Hong Kong independence'' speech. [size=5]

On 12 April 2018, around 50 people from the Hong Kong Campaign for the Advancement of Human Rights and Peace in the Philippines (HKCAHRPP) gathered near the hotel where Filipino president Rodrigo Duterte was staying at in Tsim Sha Tsui, Yau Tsim Mong District (Hong Kong) during a three-day visit. Protesters chanted anti-Duterte slogans and protested against Duterte's war on drugs, which they said was a sham used to target activists and opponents. On the same day, there were also migrant activists reported to be protesting near the hotel. [size=around 50]

assoc_actor_1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

The protest came after police in Beijing stopped Wang's wife from finishing her planned 100-kilometre march from Beijing to Tianjin to highlight his disappearance. Protesters held banners and chanted slogans calling for Wang's immediate release. [size=about 20]

On 9 April 2018, at least 10 people including members of the SoCO and some homeless individuals gathered outside of the central government offices in Central Hong Kong while the Legislative Council was having meetings to protest against the poor living conditions in the partitioned cubicles of public housing and that they would rather sit through nights at 24h fast-food restaurants. On 9 April 2018, nearly 20 people marched from the University of Hong Kong MTR station to the law faculty on campus (Western District, Hong Kong) to protest against the professor that had recently spoke about the ''independence'' of Hong Kong at a conference in Taiwan. They also delivered a petition letter to the university that asked to remove this professor from this teaching position. [size=nearly 20]

On 8 April 2018, dozens of pro-democracy activists organised by the Demosisto party gathered at Langham Place in Mong Kok, Yau Tsim Mong District (Kowloon City, Hong Kong) and conducted a flash mob protest against the controversial upcoming national anthem law. On 3 January 2018, at least five villagers and farmers from Tsiu Keng and Cheung Lek Villages, Sheung Shui protested at the government headquarters in Central district (Hong Kong) against its decision to build a road for vehicles through their agricultural lands, which caused property owners to evict residents living near it. They brought a few of their crops and held large banners. [size=at least 5]

On 1 January 2018, 800 Falun Gong practitioners marched on streets of Sham Shui Po District in Hong Kong to protest against the political persecution of their practitioners by the Chinese government. [size=800]

assoc_actor_1: CHRF: Civil Human Rights Front; PP: People Power
actor2: Private Security Forces (China)
source: Wen Wei Po; South China Morning Post
notes: On 1 January 2018, CHRF organized a march from Wan Chai to the East Wing Forecourt of the government headquarters in Admiralty, Central and Western District (Hong Kong) in opposition to last week's formal endorsement by the government of a ''co-location'' plan to set up a joint checkpoint at the West Kowloon station, which demonstrators felt would reduce Hong Kong's from Beijing. Towards the end of the demonstration, demonstrators from several groups, including People Power, broke into the East Wing Forecourt and attempted to rush onto the flag platform. They clashed with security personnel of the Government Headquarters, resulting in the injury of two demonstrators and one security personnel. Organisers said 10000 people participated but police put the turnout at 6200. [size=6200 to 10000]

On 1 January 2018, more than 60 members of DHKC launched a protest march with banners starting from Causeway Bay to the Canal Road Flyover in Wan Chai, Hong Kong, criticizing the HKSAR government for appeasing with plotters of Occupy Central campaign, and accusing organizers of Occupy Central of instigating crime among students. [size=more than 60]

actor2: Civilians (International)
notes: Hijackers took the Hong Kong-flagged Great Creation of the coast of Somalia with its 25 crew -- 24 Chinese and one Sri Lankan
